key_points: Taliban fighters captured Kabul on Aug. 15, marking the completion of their rapid offensive across Afghanistan.
Immediate chaos ensued as foreigners and Afghans rushed to leave the country, leading to several deaths.
U.S. President Joe Biden addressed the fallout of the U.S. military withdrawal on Aug. 17 amid global criticism.
Taliban spokesperson, Zabihullah Mujahid, promised respect for women's rights and no reprisals in a press conference.
Anti-Taliban protests and violent incidents, including a suicide bomb attack, occurred throughout the month.
The Taliban announced measures to tackle reports of atrocities and the economic turmoil following their takeover.
The U.S. military conducted drone strikes against Islamic State threats near Kabul airport.
U.S. Central Command announced the completion of U.S. troop withdrawal on Aug. 30.
The Taliban announced a new government on Sept. 7, and Kabul airport reopened for aid and domestic flights.
International donors pledged $1.1 billion for Afghanistan amidst a humanitarian crisis.
spokespersons: U.S. General Frank McKenzie (Head of U.S. Central Command)
